questions.question_text:
An organization is improving its web services to enable better customer engagement and self-service. The organization has a native mobile application and a rewards portal provided by a third party. The business wants to provide customers with the ability to log in once and have SSO between each of the applications.
The integrity of the identity is important so it can be propagated through to back-end systems to maintain a consistent audit trail. Which of the following authentication and authorization types BEST meet the requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CF
Not common knowledge, but OAuth does provide audit trails.

Requesting party it's say yelp.
Auth and resource is gmail.

Here is the scenario: When the authorization server gives the requesting party the authorization code to access desired info on the resource server, which by the way takes place on a front end like browser, the requesting party then uses back-end channels that provide both audit trail to swap the code for the token that can then be used on the resource server to pull the info requesting party needs. This switch between the front and back end was done for the purposes of security. 

I got this from a video lecture a while ago, and don't have the reference - sorry, but hope this helps.
OpenID doesnt maintain an audit trail, so given answer is correct

I definitely think F. OAuth is a correct answer. Reading the AIO book (p.562) it says it is "a token-based authorization standard that permits an end user's resources or account information to be shared with third parties without their password also being shared." The question specifying third parties for the rewards portal makes me think this is correct.

Not sure whether the other correct answer is SAML or OpenID. Kind of leaning toward SAML.

https://security.stackexchange.com/questions/44611/difference-between-oauth-openid-and-openid-connect-in-very-simple-term#:~:text=OpenID%20is%20about%20verifying%20a%20person%27s%20identity%20%28authentication%29.,authority%20instead%20of%20to%20a%20less%20trusted%20app.
Is there any reason to choose Social Login over OpenID?

I see no reason to use anything more than OpenID. I don't see why social login would provide feedback data. If OpenID is being used, then I don't see what SAML is needed for.
Maybe OAuth would be helpful? OAuth allows a third-party website or *application* (i.e. facebook app) to access a user’s data without the user needing to share login credentials. The question specifically states: "organization has a native mobile application."

comments.content: Oauth and OpenID are 2 separate mechanisms. Oauth is for authorization and OpenID connect is the authentication layer on top of Oauth. I would choose CF. OpenID connect also supports native and mobile apps.

You are making some valid points. As I see it:
Requirements:
1. SSO for customers
2. work with mobile application
3. work with 3rd party rewards portal
4. maintain audit trail
5. feedback data
I see how Oauth and OpenID take care of requirements 1, 2, and 3; but what about requirements 4 and 5?
thats great but there is no reasoning to this

discussion.content: Answer is AC!.

I would lean towards OpenID Connect and social login rather than SAML and OAuth. OpenID Connect can do authentication and authorization for consumer needs as opposed to SAML which is enterprise-centric. While social login can provide feedback data which the company is looking for.

comments.content: Does social login really provide feedback? I know social login can provide some information about the user, such as the user's location, and maybe email address; but that is not what I would consider "feedback." I think of feedback as comments the customers have made about the site, or service, or whatever.

questions.question_text: After the departure of a developer under unpleasant circumstances, the company is concerned about the security of the software to which the developer has access. Which of the following is the BEST way to ensure security of the code following the incident?

discussion.content:
D.
If a developer left under unpleasant circumstances, we're specifically worried that he put in backdoors or other malicious code of vulnerabilities so that he can break the application or sell access to it. Red team exercises won't necessarily find a small back door that a developer hid in a code (a red team will try to penetrate the software like an external actor, not a malicious insider), but full regression testing and code review should do it.

Selected Answer: C
"Which of the following is the BEST way to ensure security of the code following the incident?"

White Box Testing is software testing technique in which internal structure, design and coding of software are tested to verify flow of input-output and to improve design, usability and security.

C. Perform white-box testing on all impacted finished products

Regression testing is usually done after a specific change, but we have no idea at what point the developer may have put in backdoors or other malicious code into the software. White-box testing would have someone do a more thorough and all encompassing test against the software.

Maybe: C. Perform white-box testing on all impacted finished products ?
This could mean almost the same thing as D.

questions.question_text: A software company is releasing a new mobile application to a broad set of external customers. Because the software company is rapidly releasing new features, it has built in an over-the-air software update process that can automatically update the application at launch time. Which of the following security controls should be recommended by the company's security architect to protect the integrity of the update process? (Choose two.)

A Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is developing a new BIA for the organization. The CISO wants to gather requirements to determine the appropriate
RTO and RPO for the organization's ERP. Which of the following should the CISO interview as MOST qualified to provide RTO/RPO metrics?

discussion.content:
D
Business Unit Director
To determine the business need for recovery and availability, you need to consult with the person running business activities. None of the other people will know what sort of an outage or data loss the business can tolerate, which is the point of the question.

D - because it says "organization's ERP" and not specific department within organization or similar. So, the only qualified person to provide RTO/RPO metrics for the organization's ERP, in my mind, would be Business Unit Director.
MOST qualified? D. Business unit director. Although I imagine they would have to consult with some of the other listed options to provide a reasonable RPO/RTO.

Leaning towards A.

A. Data custodian - responsible for implementing and testing the plans (RTO/RPO) defined by the Data owner. Metrics implies testing or results?
B. Data owner - responsible for defining the RTO/RPO in the policy. Does real life always match policy? doesn't metrics imply something measured (vs something defined)?
D. Business unit director - The data owner is usually a senior manager (is that much different from a director??). I feel like this is pretty much redundant with data owner, as they could be the same person.

Maybe: B. Data owner?
RTO and RPO, deal with the maximum acceptable amount of time that data is not available. 
Doesn't that decision ultimately lie with data owner?
If I am responsible for the data in the ERP, then maybe I decide how long that data can be unavailable?
A. data custodian manages the actual data. This role manages servers, backups, or networks.

Maybe C. Security analyst ?
I thought it was the security analyst who is most qualified to calculate these objectives?
